title: Question 120

children: A 62-year-old woman is evaluated for a 6-month history of intermittent, painful sores on the back of her hands that worsen with sun exposure. She has no other medical problems and takes no medications.
Skin findings are
shown
Skin punch biopsy results are pending.
Which of the following is the most appropriate diagnostic test?
Porphyria cutanea tarda is a photosensitive disorder that present with scarring and blistering on sun-exposed skin, most commonly on the dorsal hands.
Porphyria cutanea tarda is most commonly associated with hepatitis C virus infection, alcohol-induced liver disease, and hemochromatosis.
The most appropriate diagnostic test is plasma and urine porphyrin levels (
Option D

). This patient likely has porphyria cutanea tarda (PCT), a photosensitive disorder that presents clinically with scarring and blistering on sun-exposed skin, most commonly the dorsal hands. Hyperpigmentation of the skin and hypertrichosis of the cheeks are also common. The photosensitivity is caused by excess porphyrins deposited in the skin that are sensitive to visible light, particularly the blue-light wavelength. PCT is the most common porphyria and typically presents in patients older than 40 years. Plasma and urine porphyrins should be measured to confirm the diagnosis of PCT to differentiate from pseudoporphyria, which presents similarly clinically but has normal plasma and urine porphyrin levels. Pseudoporphyria is commonly caused by nonsteroidal anti-inflammatory drugs, tetracyclines, and diuretics. Although skin biopsy can be performed, pathology can be nonspecific and is not necessary. PCT is most commonly associated with hepatitis C virus infection, alcohol-induced liver disease, and hemochromatosis. Testing for other susceptibility factors, such as HIV and hemochromatosis, should also be considered. Treatment for PCT is phlebotomy or twice-weekly hydroxychloroquine.

Bullous lupus erythematosus is an uncommon skin manifestation of systemic lupus erythematosus. In this condition, vesicles and bullae are localized to the neck and upper trunk and also unexposed skin. Direct immunofluorescence testing of a skin biopsy is diagnostically helpful. Antinuclear antibody testing (
Option A

) is unlikely to help in the evaluation of bullous conditions because of its lack of specificity. This patient's blistering disease is confined to her hands and is not consistent with bullous lupus erythematosus.
Anti–tissue transglutaminase antibody testing (
Option B

) is the initial step in the diagnosis of dermatitis herpetiformis, an intensely pruritic bullous disease most commonly found on the elbows, knees, and buttocks that is associated with celiac disease. This patient's clinical findings are not consistent with dermatitis herpetiformis, and anti–tissue transglutaminase antibody testing is not needed.

The onset of bullous pemphigoid is usually in adults aged 60 years or older and presents with urticarial and eczematous lesions that progress to tense bullae on an erythematous base. The most common sites of involvement are the trunk, extremity flexures, and axillary and inguinal folds. Oral involvement is present in approximately 20% of patients. Antibody tests are helping for monitoring disease activity in patients with bullous pemphigoid. This patient's findings are not consistent with bullous pemphigoid, and antibody testing (
Option C
) is not appropriate.

references: Bissell DM, Anderson KE, Bonkovsky HL. Porphyria. N Engl J Med. 2017;377:862-72.
